channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title:
Ukrainian families in Kyiv have fled to an underground subway station, where many of them have been living for about a week as Russian forces continue to attack and surround the capital.
Follow live updates from the ground. https://t.co/IMHikyhdFx https://t.co/Eohm01yJXm

Ukrainian security forces guard Maidan Square in Kyiv on Wednesday, as Russian forces continue to mass outside the city in what experts fear is an attempt to encircle the capital.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/PMRFRqpsy7 https://t.co/ebL2Xpu9ZP

The UN General Assembly adopted a resolution to condemn Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, with 141 countries voting in favor, five voting against and 35 abstaining. https://t.co/Tf36GzSSMY https://t.co/ZYykQYOHCD
Breaking News: Russia overtook the strategic hub of Kherson in southern Ukraine, making it the first major city to fall since the war began. https://t.co/CYXjDQNVkt

Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has prompted alarm in Eastern Europe, as President Vladimir Putin seeks to reclaim Russia’s sphere of influence.
“Nobody here trusted the Russians before and we certainly don’t trust them now,” one former Polish soldier said. https://t.co/YYVImVFDqF

Chinese officials told Russian officials in early February not to invade Ukraine before the end of the Winter Olympics in Beijing, according to senior Biden administration officials and a European official. https://t.co/I9FMwf4mEQ

Husbands comfort their wives. Nurses tend to newborns. A mother sees her baby for the first time.
As Russian forces close in on Kyiv, life is being brought into the world in the makeshift maternity ward of a hospital basement. https://t.co/xrSF2WuGaL https://t.co/kxykW7NOvP

The UN General Assembly will vote on Wednesday on a resolution condemning Russia for invading Ukraine and placing its nuclear defense on high alert. The resolution is highly symbolic as a measure of Russia’s isolation, though not legally binding. https://t.co/z1tXLyFCOV https://t.co/Y8cwgSKRUl

In Opinion
President Volodymyr Zelensky’s chief of staff, writing from a bunker in Ukraine with the president beside him, vowed to fight "to the last breath." https://t.co/Zjc2VF8Jvt
Breaking News: The soccer club Chelsea is for sale as Roman Abramovich, the Russian oligarch who owns the Premier League team, looks to shed assets. https://t.co/R2uxAunVlp

In Odessa, Ukraine’s biggest port city, people are building defenses as they brace for a Russian attack.
At the city’s tram authority rail yard, old steel rails are being sliced up and welded into barricades called “hedgehogs” to stop tanks. https://t.co/ckBjYLSZ44 https://t.co/7Jj9DY61Mc

Russian troops have “completely surrounded” the southern port city of Kherson as casualties mount and residents shelter in their homes, a Ukrainian official said. If captured, it would be the first major city to fall to Russia.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/Qe8Dau2Pr3

“It’s ruined,” Ilya, a 22-year-old who fled Kharkiv, said of the Ukrainian city that has been a target of Russia. “It is very bad there. They just ruined our city.”
He described a landscape of devastated buildings, failing electricity and constant fear. https://t.co/DdpEmcrcTw https://t.co/ocnNRtkJ7c

In Opinion
“I am writing this appeal from a bunker in the capital, with President Volodymyr Zelensky by my side,” says Andriy Yermak, head of the Presidential Office of Ukraine, in a guest essay. “Nothing less than our freedom — and yours — is at stake.” https://t.co/Cu4srFcrDW

Russia’s war on Ukraine has thrown a spotlight on oligarchs, most of whom amassed their wealth thanks to ties with President Vladimir Putin. Many have used London to hide or launder their fortunes, but now Britain is moving to plug embarrassing loopholes. https://t.co/GNOvP2udyR

A Ukrainian soldier was filmed reciting a Persian love poem on the eve of battle. Written by Hamid Mosadegh, it is called, “Who will tell you the news of my death?" https://t.co/CRQ0emjlFg https://t.co/VCnjtD9pEI
Boeing and Ford Motor, two major U.S. manufacturers, have suspended their business activities in Russia as the country escalated its war in Ukraine. https://t.co/Zq6PjBdYci

Following reports that Ukrainian border guards were hindering Africans trying to flee Russia’s invasion, Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, said the government would try to “solve the problem.” https://t.co/TM5pHMJ6x0 https://t.co/rcvslBgekm
The mounting death toll for Russian troops in the war on Ukraine could damage any remaining domestic support that President Vladimir Putin has for the invasion. https://t.co/8Xn2A1tzSJ

The EU agreed on new sanctions against Belarus for aiding Russia in the invasion of Ukraine. They include a ban on valuable exports of potash, used for fertilizer, as well as timber, iron, steel, cement and tobacco.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/x5NlvzUQCc

Aleksei Navalny, the most prominent critic of President Vladimir Putin, called for Russians to protest the invasion of Ukraine. Russians “must, gritting our teeth and overcoming fear, come out and demand an end to the war,” he said.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/eMsUrTK3qB

The Russian military said it fully controlled Kherson, a strategic city in Ukraine. But the claim could not be immediately verified, and Ukrainian officials said that while Kherson was surrounded, the battle for it continued.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/rUNww2qEev

Across Ukraine, families are being forced to make split-second decisions in light of Russia’s invasion: to stay, flee or take up arms to defend their country.
"I am the mother of my son," one woman said. "And I don’t know if I will see him again or not." https://t.co/IeH1PwnhGO https://t.co/kdcTRMOspW

As dawn broke in Ukraine, blasts were reported across Kyiv and air-raid sirens blared in cities across the country. A convoy of Russian tanks and mechanized vehicles moved to encircle the capital in advance of what officials fear could be a brutal siege. https://t.co/ZusClmsVAT

In his #SOTU speech, President Biden said his administration was taking steps with allies, including releasing oil reserves, to reduce economic disruptions after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. “I want you to know: We’re going to be OK,” he said. https://t.co/2woq0czOF1 https://t.co/rZEvIQRQDp

“Instead of relying on foreign supply chains, let’s make it in America,” President Biden said in his #SOTU address — setting off chants of “U.S.A.! U.S.A.!” in Congress. https://t.co/QmLjPnFFA1 https://t.co/5uuqsKsnmT

As hundreds of thousands of people fled Ukraine amid Russia’s invasion, some international students said they were mistreated by authorities and that Ukrainians received preferential treatment while traveling on trains and crossing borders. https://t.co/skLsvGFACn https://t.co/G4ICOf3k7S

"When the history of this era is written, Putin's war on Ukraine will have left Russia weaker and the rest of the world stronger."
President Biden strongly condemned the Russian invasion of Ukraine during his #SOTU address. Here are some excerpts. https://t.co/kNdU3AVDQ5

"Your love burned to ashes The jungle of my soul."
A Ukrainian soldier was filmed reciting a Persian love poem on the eve of battle. Written by Hamid Mosadegh, it is called, “Who will tell you the news of my death?" https://t.co/AVvitY8Ymr
President Biden ended his #SOTU with forward-looking positivity: "The State of the Union is strong—because you, the American people, are strong." https://t.co/aJA0F4vyNd https://t.co/JVfqmBOLHO

Russian aircraft will be banned from American airspace because of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, President Biden said in his #SOTU address. “The Russian economy is reeling, and Putin alone is the one to blame,” Biden said. https://t.co/Mv1VqV3Exr https://t.co/JlFSUjw6lD

We fact-checked President Biden's claim during the #SOTU about strong U.S. job growth.
Follow our live analysis: https://t.co/wmEgwIYSOi https://t.co/HwXEcia7IL

The U.S. and the EU have been unwilling to put sanctions on Russian energy exports in response to the country’s invasion of Ukraine. But some oil traders appear to have concluded that buying oil from Russia is just not worth the trouble. https://t.co/BUIndiZcNL

“Freedom will always triumph over tyranny.”
President Biden said during the #SOTU that President Vladimir Putin of Russia had “badly miscalculated” by invading Ukraine. Oksana Markarova, Ukraine’s ambassador to the U.S., also received a standing ovation. https://t.co/wvWci0Ynn5 https://t.co/IDY2d5WboS
Beto O’Rourke easily won the Democratic primary for governor on Tuesday. He will likely face off against Gov. Greg Abbott, the two-term Republican incumbent, in November. https://t.co/ZpReTU7L25

Oksana Markarova, Ukraine’s ambassador to the U.S., received a standing ovation during the #SOTU. She attended as First Lady Jill Biden’s guest.
Follow our live analysis of the speech: https://t.co/uCrE7y1nV5 https://t.co/XSgReWoEZ7

Apple said Tuesday it paused the sales of its products in Russia and had taken several other steps in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, including disabling features in its maps app “as a safety and precautionary measure for Ukrainian citizens.” https://t.co/FQabv9Id1E
Breaking News: President Biden will announce a U.S. ban on Russian aircraft flying through American airspace, following similar moves by other countries. https://t.co/m4lm7qeWhr
Oksana Markarova, Ukraine’s ambassador to the U.S., is set to join Jill Biden in the first lady’s box for the president’s State of the Union address. https://t.co/dE4Iiui9g0

President Biden started his State of the Union speech focused on Russia's invasion of Ukraine, returning to a core theme of his foreign policy. Watch the rest of the #SOTU live: https://t.co/ZDwPpr8QZz https://t.co/Ji7OBqyZKp

Several U.S. states announced plans to sever or reconsider their financial ties to Russia, with moves ranging from outright divestment, as in the case of the Connecticut pension system, to restrictions on the sale of Russian vodka in Iowa and Ohio. https://t.co/6VQ2H0mYvk https://t.co/lAwAELzHnP

"Putin's war was premeditated and unprovoked," President Biden plans to say during the State of the Union. "He thought the West and NATO wouldn't respond. And he thought he could divide us here at home. Putin was wrong." Read excerpts from Biden's speech. https://t.co/KXlKIcDkbf

Exxon Mobil said Tuesday that it would end its involvement in a large oil and natural gas project in Russia, becoming the latest Western oil company to announce that it is leaving the country after Russia invaded Ukraine. https://t.co/xJ1R4NXcGz

Jewish groups and institutions around the world condemned a strike in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, in the area of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center, where tens of thousands of Jews were killed by the Nazis in a two-day massacre during World War II. https://t.co/dTQLxBDsQr

President Biden will set out steps to protect nursing home residents and hold providers accountable for unsafe and substandard care as part of his State of the Union address, including expanding inspections and penalties on “bad actor” facilities. https://t.co/FBC6VRfb8E

Russia appeared to target civilian areas with increasingly powerful weapons on Tuesday, damaging major cities, including Kharkiv, and dramatically raising the risk of civilian deaths.
See the latest map of the areas occupied by Russian forces. https://t.co/H6KavmVVdt

The International Skating Union barred Russian athletes from performing at the world championships in three weeks. The ban would keep Anna Shcherbakova, the reigning Olympic champion, from defending her 2021 world title. https://t.co/XaBBvHE6yn

A huge ship that had caught fire and was transporting about 4,000 luxury cars — including 1,000 Porsches and 200 Bentleys — sank on Tuesday, the company that managed the vessel said. Environmental groups had been deeply concerned that the ship would sink. https://t.co/eL0pc4Oagi

A large explosion struck Freedom Square in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, on Tuesday, directly in front of the city’s administrative building. At least seven people were killed, officials said. https://t.co/6gQ6t429JZ https://t.co/Opda9ZESgO

This is the Okhmadet Children’s Hospital in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, where parents and doctors tended to sick children on Monday, even as Russian forces closed in on the city.
Follow live updates from our journalists on the ground: https://t.co/uFqd7EbpOV https://t.co/7LgnAjLIMD
